2.  The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled
The Brenntag - Ft. Wayne facility's primary activities encompass distribution of chemical products.  There are currently two regulated substances present at the facility.   The regulated substances are received prepackaged in different  containers.  The materials are only handled for resell to customers.  

3.  The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps  
The Brenntag - Ft. Wayne facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set forth under 40 CFR Part 68 of the EPA.  The facility was designed and constructed in accordance with the NFPA 30 -1996 Standard.
The following sections briefly describe the elements and RMP job responsibilities of the release prevention program that is currently in place at the stationary source.

Process Safety Information - Regional Manager of Health Safety & Quality
Brenntag - Ft. Wayne maintains a detailed record of written safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes.

Process Hazard Analysis - Regional Manager of Health Safety & Quality
Brenntag - Ft. Wayne conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the distribution processes are identified and controlled efficiently. Executive Summary

The Brenntag Great Lakes, LLC - Ft. Wayne facility is a chemical warehouse and distribution facility, located in Ft. Wayne, Indiana.  Brenntag Great Lakes, LLC is part of Brenntag North America, Inc.  Brenntag Great Lakes, LLC is an advanced distribution company providing customers worldwide with products, chemicals and advanced materials.  Our major operations are located in the Midwest and employ over 200 people.

It is the world-wide policy of Brenntag to design, blend and distribute its products, and to manage those products throughout their life cycle in a manner that protects the environment and safeguards employees, customers, and the public from unacceptable risk.  This facility participates in the Responsible Distribution Process program of the National Association of Chemical Distributors.  The Distribution Process program brings chemical distribution plants and local communities together through communication and cooperative emergency planning.  It is our company policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local regulations. 

Brenntag maintains health, safety, and environmental manuals, which contain company policies for risk management, training, product stewardship, community outreach, and hazard communication among other topics.  The manuals also include emergency action plans, emergency response plans, and transportation emergency plans.  The facility is in compliance with OSHA regulations.

In accordance with the RMP Submit Users' Manual 2009, the following elements and their descriptions have been included in this Executive Summary:

1.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Brenntag - Ft. Wayne is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is inherent to a comprehensive accidental release prevention program in place that covers areas such as; design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the vario

on emergency procedures, and participating in outreach activities, which include: educating and training customers, fire departments, and emergency response teams.  Brenntag practices continuous training of emergency procedures through regular safety meetings, and all incidents and near misses are thoroughly investigated and reviewed by the Health and Safety personnel at each facility.  

Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of the Brenntag - Ft. Wayne accidental release prevention program.  Brenntag - Ft. Wayne constantly strives to improve the safety of the processes at the Ft. Wayne facility through both the incident investigation program, and the safety committee.  Brenntag - Ft. Operating Procedures - Traffic/Warehouse Supervisor
Brenntag - Ft. Wayne maintains written operating procedures for the purposes of safely conducting activities associated with the distribution processes.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as used in normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved with the processes.

Training - Regional Manager of Health Safety & Quality
Brenntag - Ft. Wayne has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees that are operating processes are completely competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  New employees receive basic training in process operations followed by on-the-job supervision until they are deemed competent to work independently.  Refresher training is provided at least every three (3) years, and more frequently, as needed.

Mechanical Integrity - Traffic/Warehouse Supervisor
Brenntag - Ft. Wayne carries out highly documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper functions.  Maintenance checks are performed on process equipment also includes lift trucks and tractor/trailer trucks.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training, as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner. Outside contractors also participate in the maintenance process.

Management of Change - Regional Manager of Health Safety & Quality
Written procedures are in place at Brenntag - Ft. Wayne to manage changes in chemicals, technology, equipm

ent and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions, are promptly made aware of the modification and offered appropriate training.

Pre-startup Reviews - Regional Manager of Health Safety & Quality
Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications of established processes, are conducted as a regular practice at Brenntag - Ft. Wayne.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits - Regional Manager of Health Safety & Quality
Brenntag - Ft. Wayne conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set forth under the RMP rule are being implemented.  These audits are carried out at least every 3 years and any corrective actions resulting from the audits are undertaken in a safe and timely manner.

Incident Investigation - Regional Manager of Health Safety & Quality
Brenntag - Ft. Wayne promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in, a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are conducted to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as to determine corrective actions that will prevent the release from reoccurring.  All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

Employee Participation - Branch Manager
Brenntag - Ft. Wayne truly believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  In addition, employees have access to all information developed for the RMP rule along with information resulting from process hazard analyses.

Contractors - Traffic/Warehouse Supervisor
On occasion, Brenntag - Ft. Wayne hires contractors to

conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is conducted.  Brenntag - Ft. Wayne has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes.  Contractors are also informed of procedures for emergency response in the unlikely event that a regulated substance is accidentally released.

4.  Five-year Accident History
Brenntag - Ft. Wayne has had zero accident releases in five years at this facility. 

5.  Emergency Response Plan
Brenntag - Ft. Wayne has a written emergency response plan in place to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.

To ensure proper functioning, emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes that take place within the processes that would require a modified emergency response.

The Emergency Response Plan has been reviewed, coordinated and verified with Allen County, which is the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).

6.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Brenntag safety program is designed to prevent fires, explosions, and accidental chemical releases.  The program requires safety audits, inspection, maintenance programs, and safety training for employees and contract workers.  Facility personnel are always encouraged to listen to the concerns of the community and to consider these concerns when designing and implementing process safety systems.
